awd_titl_txt: Coupling Small-particle Adsorbents with Membranes for Trace-containment Removal in Water Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1236070
David Ladner, Tanju Karanfil, Thompson Mefford

Recent technological advances have resulted in promising nano- and micro-sized (small-particle) materials that can remove synthetic organic chemicals (SOCs) from drinking water. These small-particle adsorbents, such as graphene platelets and super-fine powdered activated carbon (S-PAC), show faster adsorption kinetics than larger materials. Small-particle adsorbents also perform better in the presence of natural organic matter (NOM), which means they may be better in real-world situations. However, a practical problem exists with small particles: preventing their passage into the finished drinking water. Microfiltration (MF) and ultrafiltration (UF) membrane processes can be effective, but pore blockage by the small materials decreases water flux and increases the energy required for separations. Thus there exists a quandary: small particles are best for SOC adsorption, but large particles are easier to remove. A major advancement would be to find materials and conditions where SOC adsorption is high, NOM competition is low, and little energy is required to remove the adsorbents. This project is built around three main Aims: (1) Determine the properties of small-particle adsorbents that enable SOC adsorption with minimal interference by NOM. (2) Determine the extent to which small-particle adsorbents will foul membranes of various pore size and examine the particle breakthrough propensity. (3) Explore engineering methods to achieve SOC adsorption with minimal energy required for membrane separations. In Aim 1 NOM will be extracted from raw water and from coagulated/flocculated water to test competitive adsorption of SOCs. In some experiments 3H-labeled NOM and 14C-labeled atrazine will be used to investigate mass-transport mechanisms. In Aim 2 membrane flux and particle breakthrough will be measured when removing small-particle adsorbents, taking into account the effects of aggregation. Carbon spheres will be produced with well-controlled particle size to carefully study particle size effects. In Aim 3 a reactor/membrane setup will be used that will allow SOC adsorption by dispersed particles before inducing aggregation that is expected to decrease fouling and membrane breakthrough. Adsorption capacity and kinetics are commonly investigated for novel materials, but here both competitive adsorption effects and small-particle removal requirements will be explored simultaneously to learn how these phenomena are interconnected. For example, the structure of an aggregate of small particles will affect both adsorption kinetics and membrane transport. Novel techniques will be used to investigate the phenomena, such as the radiolabeled NOM and atrazine for detection levels that have not previously been achieved in competitive adsorption studies. Further, the concept of induced adsorbent aggregation in membrane systems has not been previously explored.

This project may lead to engineered unit processes specifically designed to efficiently remove SOCs of concern, like personal care products and endocrine disrupting compounds, from drinking water sources to protect human health. The study will also elucidate desirable materials properties, giving researchers targets for which they can aim in future materials development. Although SOC removal is the focus, this is in fact a hybrid system that will allow multiple treatment objectives in a single process (i.e., the control of both small molecular weight contaminants and microbial contaminants). Moving into the future, sustainable water treatment will require low-footprint and low-energy processes, which are the dual objectives here.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The goal of this project is summarized succinctly in its title: Coupling Small-particle Adsorbents with Membranes for Trace-containment Removal in Water Treatment. The investigators were interested in finding ways to remove various organic contaminants from drinking water. They (and others) had recently found that adsorbents with very small particle sizes might work better than conventional adsorbents that were only available commercially in larger sizes. This work evaluated the benefits of using the smaller materials. A key with small materials is their separation from the finished drinking water. Membranes with very small pore size can accomplish that removal, so the combined use of the small-particle adsorbents with membranes was the focus of this work.

Intellectual merit

The first effort for this project was to compare two types of small-particle adsorbent materials: graphene and superfine powdered activated carbon (S-PAC). Early in the work we determined that S-PAC had better contaminant removal capabilities than graphene, so we focused on S-PAC for the remainder of the project. This is an important finding because while graphene is a recently discovered and interesting material, it is much more expensive to produce than S-PAC; focusing on S-PAC means the likelihood for commercial viability is greater.

The main hypothesis of this work is that there exists a tradeoff between energy requirements and contaminant removal capabilities. Small-particles have fast adsorption kinetics due to shorter travel paths for contaminants to reach adsorption sites. These particles can also work more efficiently in river and lake waters because the natural organic matter in those sources does not hinder contaminant removal in small particles the same way it does with larger particles. The tradeoff is that the smaller particles require more energy for removal because they are not as easily settled or filtered out of the water like larger particles. This tradeoff is shown by the red trend line in Figure 1. This research was geared toward finding whether some combinations of small-particle adsorbents and membranes could deviate from the trend line, such that good contaminant removal could be achieved with lower energy.

Figure 2 shows one set of promising results. Atrazine was the contaminant of interest here. (Atrazine is an herbicide used heavily in the Midwest United States and many other places around the world). Atrazine removal percent is on the X-axis while water flux through a membrane is shown on the Y-axis. High water flux means low energy, so higher flux is better. The symbol sizes in Figure 2 are related to the size of the particles. We can see that our hypothesis is supported in this data set. In general better contaminant removal is achieved with smaller particles while flux decreases (and energy increases); however, some materials were identified (marked by the red box) where contaminant removal was good, but the energy cost was not significant. These data suggest a viable path forward for full-scale use of small-particle adsorbents.

Another important scientific aspect of this work was a new understanding of what happens to S-PAC when it is created by bead milling from the parent PAC material. Through a suite of analytical techniques we determined the chemical changes that occur. One important finding was that the adsorbent surfaces are oxygenated during milling, and that most of the oxygenation occurs on the outer edges of the particles. This oxygenation may mean the adsorbents will work better for some contaminants, but worse for others.

A parallel effort during this project was investigating a "bottom-up" technique of creating S-PAC adsorbents from simple sugars and polysaccharides. This could circumvent the traditional "top-down" activated carbon grinding and wet milling process, enabling a more cost-effective method of adsorbent creation. Figure 3 shows one sample of bottom-up derived carbon spheres.

Broader Impacts

Higher quality water at a reduced price is the ultimate expected impact from this work. This project may have a societal impact by providing a means for removing contaminants from public drinking water supplies. We have elucidated the properties and performance of new materials and approaches that make contaminant removal cheaper than current technology. That is expected to improve both our societal and economic sustainability.
